title: 109_hr5340
content: The Upper Mississippi River Basin Protection Act includes provisions for sediment and nutrient monitoring network establishment, data collection responsibilities, collaboration with existing monitoring efforts, reporting requirements, and national research council assessment. Additionally, it addresses computer modeling and research in two separate titles. The Upper Mississippi River Basin Protection Act includes provisions for sediment and nutrient monitoring, electronic information distribution, reporting requirements, authorization of appropriations, cost-sharing, and definitions. The Upper Mississippi River Basin Protection Act defines key terms such as the Upper Mississippi River Basin, Upper Mississippi River Stewardship Initiative, and sound science related to monitoring nutrient and sediment loss in the watershed. The Upper Mississippi River Basin Protection Act defines terms and emphasizes the importance of sound science in monitoring nutrient and sediment loss in the watershed. This involves quantifying sources, transport, and fate of nutrients and sediment, as well as evaluating the impact of treatment methods and conservation measures. Sound science necessitates using established protocols for data collection and analysis, along with peer review of results and findings. The Upper Mississippi River Basin Protection Act emphasizes the reliance on sound science for Federal investments in the region. Title I focuses on establishing a sediment and nutrient monitoring network. The Upper Mississippi River Basin Protection Act establishes a sediment and nutrient monitoring network to identify sources, quantify processes, record changes over time, provide data for computer modeling, and identify major sources of sediment and nutrients in the region. The Upper Mississippi River Basin Protection Act establishes a sediment and nutrient monitoring network to identify major sources of sediment and nutrients in the region. The Secretary of the Interior will implement this through the United States Geological Survey. SEC. 102. DATA COLLECTION AND STORAGE RESPONSIBILITIES. The Secretary of the Interior will establish guidelines for sediment and nutrient monitoring data collection, storage, and reporting. Data from Upper Mississippi River Basin monitoring will be released to the public with generic identifiers. Privacy protection measures will be in place for data collected in the Basin. The data collected in the Upper Mississippi River Basin will be subject to mandatory disclosure provisions but can only be released as specified in subsection (b). SEC. 103. RELATIONSHIP TO EXISTING SEDIMENT AND NUTRIENT MONITORING. The Secretary of the Interior will inventory existing sediment and nutrient monitoring efforts to understand overlap, data gaps, and redundancies. They will integrate these efforts into the required monitoring network and make use of existing data and programs from various entities. The Secretary of the Interior will coordinate with the long-term estuary assessment project to develop the sediment and nutrient monitoring network required by section 101. The Secretary of the Interior will collaborate with other monitoring programs to establish the sediment and nutrient monitoring network. Reporting to Congress on the network's development is required within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The National Research Council will assess water resources in the Upper Mississippi River Basin. SEC. 201. COMPUTER MODELING AND RESEARCH OF SEDIMENT AND NUTRIENT SOURCES. The Upper Mississippi River Stewardship Initiative requires the establishment of a modeling program by the Director of the United States Geological Survey to identify significant sources of sediment and nutrients in the Upper Mississippi River Basin. Computer modeling will be used to pinpoint subwatersheds contributing to sediment and nutrient loss for targeted reduction efforts. The program includes models to relate nutrient and sediment loss to landscape, land use, and management practices, as well as models defining river channel nutrient transformation processes. Models will define river channel nutrient transformation processes and collect ancillary information in GIS format to support modeling and management use, including land use, soils, elevation, sediment and nutrient reduction actions, and remotely sensed data. The Director of the US Geological Survey will establish an Internet system within 90 days to provide information on programs, sediment/nutrient levels, and successful projects in the Upper Mississippi River Basin. Reporting requirements are also outlined. SEC. 203. REPORTING REQUIREMENTS. The Director of the US Geological Survey will provide annual reports on monitoring activities in the Upper Mississippi River Basin and progress reports on modeling activities every three years. SEC. 301 authorizes $6,250,000 annually for the US Geological Survey activities, with funds allocated for the Cooperative Water Program and Hydrologic Networks. $650,000 is designated for the National Research Council assessment. SEC. 302 outlines cost-sharing requirements. SEC. 302 states that funds for the US Geological Survey Cooperative Water Program must adhere to cost-sharing requirements specified in a previous law. SEC. 303 specifies that the Secretary of the Interior's authority under this Act will end 10 years after enactment.
